metadata.title: Banking Industry IAM Maturity Self-Assessment v2.1
metadata.assessmentGuidance: For each question, select the option that BEST describes your CURRENT state. Consider both technical implementation and governance processes. Look for specific evidence points mentioned in options to make accurate selections.

domains.name: General / Mandatory Questions with Context Usage Notes
domains.description: These questions are mandatory and should be answered before assessing any domain-specific question. Answers here feed context into all subsequent domain assessments. They ensure each domain question has the baseline technical and governance context to interpret maturity accurately.

questions.text: Is the IAM system fully integrated with the HR system to get authoritative user data such as roles, designations, employment status, and cost centers?
questions.clarification: This question establishes the authoritative source of identity data. Answers here influence all ILM questions (e.g., joiner/mover/leaver processes, lifecycle enforcement), AG questions (role/SOD mapping, approvals), and PAM (privileged account assignments). Without authoritative HR integration, downstream governance, certifications, and audit evidence may be incomplete or unreliable.

options.description: IAM is not integrated with HR. User data is manually maintained, leading to errors, delays, and inconsistencies.
Partial integration exists. Some attributes (e.g., employee ID, name) are imported, but roles, designations, and cost centers are inconsistent or delayed. Manual reconciliation is required.
Most critical HR attributes are integrated, roles and designations are partially synchronized. Exceptions exist for subsidiaries, affiliates, or contractors. Conflict resolution is ad hoc.

Integration is robust across all business units, subsidiaries, and affiliates. Role, designation, and employment data are authoritative, synchronized, and conflicts are resolved through a defined attribute contract.

Integration is authoritative, fully enforced, auditable, and continuous. All HR-derived attributes drive SOD, entitlement assignments, lifecycle actions, and compliance. Conflicts are systematically resolved using an enforced attribute contract.

questions.text: Are there disconnected applications or systems where manual IAM actions are required (e.g., provisioning, deprovisioning, or entitlement updates)?
questions.clarification: This informs scope and exception management across all domains. In ILM, it highlights potential delays or inconsistencies in lifecycle processing. In AG, it identifies gaps in access governance. For PAM and MFA, disconnected systems represent high-risk areas where automation and enforcement may not apply. This sets the risk context for auditors and regulators.

options.description: Most critical systems require manual IAM actions. No centralized governance exists for disconnected applications.
Some disconnected applications are documented, but processes remain partially manual and error-prone.
Manual actions exist only for a small set of low-risk applications. Exceptions are documented and risk-assessed periodically.
Manual IAM actions are rare, formally documented, risk-scored, and approved. Governance ensures exceptions do not compromise compliance.
Disconnected applications are minimized or eliminated. Any remaining manual actions are fully auditable, risk-aware, and integrated into IAM reporting and governance processes.

questions.text: Are user roles, entitlements, and SOD rules centrally defined and authoritative?
questions.clarification: This defines the baseline governance model. Answers here directly influence AG questions on role maintenance, SoD enforcement, access certifications, and policy compliance. In ILM, it impacts mover/role-change processes. For PAM, it determines how privileged access aligns with role definitions and SoD controls.

options.description: Roles and entitlements are ad hoc, inconsistently applied, and SOD rules are absent.
Some roles and SOD rules exist, but enforcement is weak and exceptions are frequent.
Roles and SOD rules are centrally defined for most critical applications. Exceptions exist for non-core or legacy applications.
Roles, entitlements, and SOD rules are authoritative, centrally maintained, enforced across most applications, and documented. Exceptions are formally managed.
Roles, entitlements, and SOD rules are fully authoritative, enforced, auditable, and continuously reviewed. Exceptions are risk-scored, approved, and documented in real-time.

questions.text: Are IAM lifecycle actions (joiner, mover, leaver) driven by authoritative HR and role data?
questions.clarification: This sets the automation and enforcement baseline for identity lifecycle management. It affects ILM questions on timeliness, reconciliation, and exceptions, and also informs AG questions around access request enforcement, certifications, and exception handling. For PAM, this drives privileged account creation/revocation.

options.description: Lifecycle actions are manually triggered; HR data is rarely referenced.
HR data partially drives lifecycle actions, but manual reconciliation is required.
Most lifecycle actions use HR and role data. Some exceptions exist for contractors, subsidiaries, or affiliates.
Lifecycle actions are fully driven by authoritative HR and role data, including subsidiaries and affiliates. Exceptions are documented and risk-assessed.
Lifecycle actions are fully automated, enforced, auditable, and risk-aware. HR, role, and employment data drive all IAM provisioning, access changes, and deprovisioning.

questions.text: Are periodic access certifications and governance reviews integrated with authoritative user data and role assignments?
questions.clarification: This defines the audit and compliance context. Answers here influence AG questions on governance effectiveness, policy enforcement, exception handling, and regulatory compliance. It also informs Monitoring & Audit questions by establishing the baseline for log review, reporting, and exception detection.

options.description: Access reviews are ad hoc, manual, and disconnected from HR or role data.
Partial reviews exist, but HR and role data are inconsistently applied, and exceptions are unmanaged.
Most critical access certifications integrate HR and role data. Some low-risk applications or exceptions are excluded.
All access certifications integrate authoritative HR and role data, enforce policies, and exceptions are risk-assessed and documented
Access certifications and governance are authoritative, auditable, risk-aware, automated where feasible, and continuously improved.

domains.name: Identity Lifecycle Management (ILM) â€“ Enhanced Clarifications
domains.description: Automated provisioning, deprovisioning, and management of employee and internal identities through integration with authoritative sources.

questions.text: Are authoritative identity sources (e.g., HR systems) integrated and trusted for identity provisioning?
questions.clarification: Consider if there are multiple identity sources across subsidiaries, affiliates, or business units.How are conflicts resolved when the same user exists in more than one authoritative source? Is there a defined Attribute Contract to determine which source takes precedence? Are all identity sources auditable and aligned with regulatory requirements (e.g., SOX, GLBA)? Are these sources actively enforced in provisioning, not optional?

options.description: No single trusted identity source exists. Identity provisioning is ad hoc, often manual, and inconsistent. Conflicts between multiple sources are resolved informally, without documented rules. Audit and regulatory requirements are not fully met.
Some authoritative sources exist, but integration is partial. Conflicts between multiple sources are inconsistently resolved. Manual overrides are frequent, and audit trails are incomplete.

Authoritative identity sources are identified, integrated with IAM, and mostly trusted. Attribute conflicts between multiple sources are resolved using documented rules, but enforcement is not consistent across all applications or subsidiaries. Auditability is partial.

All authoritative sources, including subsidiaries and affiliates, are fully integrated and trusted. Conflicts are resolved using a well-defined Attribute Contract and enforced consistently. Audit trails are complete, and the process meets regulatory and compliance standards.

Identity sources are authoritative, integrated, enforced, auditable, and continuously monitored. Conflicts are automatically resolved per policy, with full logging and reporting. The process is risk-aware, measurable, and optimized across the enterprise and regulated banking environment.

questions.text: How are new user identities (Joiners) created and validated across systems?
questions.clarification: Are identity creation processes automated or manual? Is integration with HR systems used to automatically derive roles, entitlements, or approvals? Are validation checks in place to prevent duplicate or conflicting accounts? Are timing and completion of joiner provisioning monitored and auditable? Are onboarding workflows consistent across subsidiaries and cloud/SaaS applications?

options.description: New user accounts are manually created without consistent validation. Duplicate or conflicting accounts are common. Integration with HR or other authoritative sources is minimal or absent.
Joiner processes exist but are partially automated. Some HR data is leveraged for identity creation, but validation and duplicate detection are inconsistent. Auditability is limited.
Joiner processes are automated for core applications, leveraging HR and authoritative sources. Validation checks exist but may not cover all systems or subsidiaries. Exceptions are manually managed.

Joiner provisioning is fully automated across all systems, including cloud/SaaS. Role and entitlement derivation from HR data is enforced. Duplicate or conflicting accounts are prevented. Auditable logs exist for all joiner activities.

Joiner processes are enterprise-wide, fully integrated, and auditable. Automation includes subsidiaries, affiliates, and third-party systems. Role/entitlement derivation enforces SoD, with metrics and risk monitoring continuously applied. Exceptions are rare, documented, and risk-assessed.

questions.text: How are role or responsibility changes (Movers) applied and reconciled across all applications?
questions.clarification: Are mover processes automated or manual? Are changes reflected in all connected systems, including cloud, SaaS, and affiliate applications? Is Segregation of Duties (SoD) enforced during role changes? Are conflicts between roles detected and reconciled systematically? Are exceptions documented, auditable, and risk-assessed?

options.description: Role changes are manual, inconsistent, and often delayed. Reconciliation is ad hoc, with frequent SoD violations and undocumented conflicts.
Mover processes exist for core applications but are only partially automated. Conflicts and SoD violations may occur and are resolved manually. Audit coverage is limited.

Mover changes are automated for primary systems, with reconciliation processes in place. SoD enforcement is partially applied. Some audit trails exist, but subsidiaries and cloud systems may be excluded.

Role changes are automated and reconciled across all applications, including affiliates. SoD violations are detected and resolved per policy. Complete auditable records exist for regulatory compliance.

Mover processes are enterprise-wide, automated, enforced, auditable, and risk-aware. SoD enforcement is fully integrated, conflicts are resolved automatically, and metrics/reporting enable continuous improvement.

questions.text: How is access removed for departing users (Leavers) and how quickly?
questions.clarification: Are leaver processes automated across all applications? Are orphaned accounts minimized or eliminated? Are deprovisioning timelines monitored against policy SLAs? Are exceptions (e.g., retained access for contractors or projects) managed and risk-scored? Are cloud/SaaS and affiliate applications included in deprovisioning?

options.description: Access removal is manual, inconsistent, and often delayed, leaving orphaned accounts. No formal SLAs or audit logs exist.
Some systems have defined leaver processes, but coverage is partial. Orphaned accounts are common, and SLAs are not consistently enforced. Auditability is limited.
Automated leaver processes exist for core systems. Timing and completion are monitored but may exclude subsidiaries, cloud, or SaaS applications. Exceptions require manual intervention.

Leaver processes are automated across all systems and applications. Timeliness and compliance are enforced per policy, and orphaned accounts are minimized. Audit logs are complete, including exceptions and approvals.

Leaver processes are fully automated, auditable, risk-aware, and measurable across the enterprise. Orphaned accounts are prevented, exceptions are rare and documented, and SLA compliance is continuously monitored.

questions.text: Are lifecycle processes timely, standardized, and enforceable across all systems?
questions.clarification: Are joiner, mover, and leaver processes standardized enterprise-wide? Are workflows enforced through IAM automation rather than relying on manual steps? Are exceptions or deviations documented and managed? Are disconnected or legacy systems flagged for monitoring or remediation? Are all processes aligned with regulatory requirements and internal risk policies?

options.description: Lifecycle processes are ad hoc, inconsistent, and rarely enforced. Timing is unmonitored, and exceptions are unmanaged.
Some processes exist but are only partially standardized. Enforcement is inconsistent, and timing is irregular. Disconnected systems may be excluded.
Lifecycle processes are standardized and timely for core systems. Enforcement is applied for most activities but may be inconsistent for affiliates, subsidiaries, or SaaS systems.
Processes are enterprise-wide, standardized, timely, and enforced. Exceptions are documented and risk-managed. Audit and regulatory requirements are met.

Processes are fully enforced, auditable, measurable, and continuously improved. Timing, standardization, and enforcement cover all systems, including cloud, SaaS, affiliates, and subsidiaries. Metrics inform risk-aware governance.

questions.text: How are exceptions (e.g., contractors, temporary users) handled and audited?
questions.clarification: Are temporary accounts time-bound, risk-rated, and policy-driven? Are approvals enforced, logged, and auditable? Are exceptions centrally tracked and periodically reviewed? Are privileged or sensitive accesses subjected to additional controls? Is the process designed to minimize risk exposure in regulated banking environments?

options.description: Exceptions are ad hoc, undocumented, and rarely audited. Temporary accounts may persist indefinitely.
Some exception processes exist but are inconsistently applied. Auditing is partial, and risk assessment is limited.
Exceptions are managed according to policy, with time-bound access and periodic audits. Some risk assessment exists but may not cover all applications.
Exception handling is standardized, auditable, time-bound, and risk-rated. Approvals are enforced, and documentation supports regulatory compliance.

Exception management is fully enforced, auditable, risk-aware, and measurable. Temporary accounts are automatically removed, approvals and deviations are tracked, and continuous improvement is applied.

questions.text: Are there any disconnected applications requiring manual IAM actions?
questions.clarification: Are these applications documented, and is their risk assessed? Are compensating controls in place (e.g., periodic access review, manual approval logs)? Is there a plan to integrate these applications into the IAM system? Are cloud, SaaS, or affiliate applications considered? How is the gap between automated and manual processes monitored and mitigated?

options.description: Many critical applications are disconnected. IAM actions are mostly manual, untracked, and risky.
Some disconnected applications exist, with partial compensating controls. Manual actions are inconsistent and not fully auditable.
Disconnected applications are documented, and manual actions are tracked for high-risk users. Compensating controls are partially applied.
Manual processes for disconnected systems are minimized, documented, auditable, and risk-managed. Integration plans exist for all gaps.

Disconnected applications are rare. Any remaining manual actions are fully auditable, risk-assessed, and integrated into enterprise governance and reporting. Continuous improvement ensures eventual automation.

questions.text: How is identity data quality ensured, reconciled, and verified?
questions.clarification: Are automated reconciliation jobs in place across systems? How are data discrepancies detected and resolved? Are audit trails maintained for reconciliation activities? Is there a defined data quality standard (e.g., completeness, accuracy, consistency) for identities? Are metrics collected and reported to management for governance and risk purposes?

options.description: Identity data is inconsistent, manually maintained, and rarely reconciled. Errors and duplicates are common.
Some reconciliation exists but is partial. Auditability is limited, and errors are often corrected manually.
Automated reconciliation and verification exist for core systems. Metrics exist but may not cover all subsidiaries or cloud applications.
Identity data quality is enforced, reconciled, and verified across all systems. Audit trails exist, and discrepancies are escalated and resolved.

Data quality is fully automated, auditable, measurable, risk-aware, and continuously improved. Reconciliation covers all applications, subsidiaries, and SaaS systems. Metrics drive governance decisions.

questions.text: How are lifecycle process deviations detected, escalated, and resolved?
questions.clarification: Are automated monitoring and alerts in place for joiner, mover, and leaver deviations? Are deviations risk-rated and escalated based on criticality (e.g., privileged access, high-risk users)? Are corrective actions documented and tracked to closure? Are lessons learned applied to improve future processes? Is deviation reporting auditable and presented to management or audit teams?

options.description: Deviations are rarely detected, unmanaged, and risk exposure is high. Escalation is informal.
Some monitoring exists, but deviations are inconsistently detected and resolved. Audit trails are incomplete.
Deviations are detected for core systems, escalated per policy, and resolved manually. Some risk assessment exists.
Deviations are automatically detected, escalated, documented, and resolved. Risk assessment is applied, and regulatory reporting is possible.
Deviations are fully automated, auditable, risk-aware, measurable, and reported to management. Continuous improvement reduces recurrence across all systems.

questions.text: Are lifecycle processes measurable, reported, and continuously improved?
questions.clarification: Are metrics defined for key lifecycle activities (e.g., time to provision, orphaned accounts, exceptions)? Are reports generated periodically and reviewed by management and audit teams? Is continuous improvement applied based on metrics, incidents, and regulatory feedback? Are lifecycle KPIs aligned with risk and compliance requirements? Are improvements implemented across all business units, subsidiaries, and cloud/SaaS systems?

options.description: No metrics or reports exist. Continuous improvement is absent. Governance and audit are limited.
Some basic metrics exist but are inconsistent. Reporting is irregular, and improvement efforts are ad hoc.
Key lifecycle metrics are defined and reported for core systems. Continuous improvement exists but may not cover subsidiaries or cloud/SaaS.
Lifecycle processes are measurable and reported enterprise-wide. Continuous improvement is applied based on metrics and incidents. Audit and regulatory requirements are satisfied.

Metrics cover all applications, subsidiaries, and SaaS/cloud systems. Reporting is automated, auditable, and risk-aware. Continuous improvement is embedded in governance and decision-making processes.
